Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Creating a Unified Framework for the Quantitative Study of Animal Aggregations
Award.AbstractNarration:
Animal social behavior occurs in many species, often with spectacular visual results. In the past, studies have either focused on (1) why animals join groups, or (2) the "traffic rules" animals use to position themselves within groups. However, there is currently no theory to describe how one would go about connecting these two ideas. This project will create a single theoretical system that explicitly integrates the two concepts by combining existing models of animal social behavior and will generate a new computer toolkit to allow the development of the new model. The primary results of this project will be a new, unifying theory of animal social behavior and a new user-friendly toolkit to conduct behavioral analysis. By developing new theory and providing new tools to study social behavior, this project will integrate research and education and transform the way students learn about science. To make the new toolkit available to the widest possible audience, all computer programs and data will be stored in the WSSU library digital archive at http://www.wssu.edu/cg-okelly-library/archives/digitalcollection.aspx.

This project will have broader impact on the scientific community by providing a new framework for future investigators, and by providing them with a user-friendly computer toolkit. This project will have broader impact in education because it will popularize the science of behavioral ecology, and broaden participation in science by under-represented groups. A new seminar course and independent student projects will help increase the popularity of behavioral ecology on campus. Students will also maintain a project web site and develop "smartphone" applications based on the research toolkit. These student-led projects will serve as portals to incite interest in behavioral ecology by the general population, allowing the project's content to reach thousands.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This CAREER project enabled the PI to create the fundamental tools needed for a successful career as both a researcher and educator in behavioral ecology.

The intellectual merit of this project centered around developing a single, comprehensive computer modeling software package for studying animal aggregation. The model the PI developed (the "dynamic-linkage" program) is modular, and capable of running any aggregation model whose behavioral rules have been imported. Because it is object-oriented in design, one need only add user-defined objects with custom movement rules, and the user-friendly program will do the rest. The program is freely available on the open-source website "source forge," and its completion accomplished the major goal of project's research arm. One paper was published using this modeling tool, and two more are in early stages of composition.

The broader impacts of this project centered around popularizing behavioral ecology with students, particularly those from under-represented groups. Toward that end, the PI recruited 22 different students into the research lab during the project's lifespan, 21 of whom were from under-represented groups -- including 19 African-Americans, one Latino, and one student with a documented disability. Research with these students led to 21 presentations at local, national, and international conferences, including 14 presentations with student co-authors, nine of which had students as the lead author. Several student researchers have gone on to graduate or professional school, including one who received a Master's degree in animal behavior and is now studying behavioral ecology in a doctoral program in Germany. This hands-on research with students accomplished the major goals of sparking interest in behavioral ecology and attracting members of under-represented groups to the field.

Additionally, 45 students -- all from under-represented groups -- took the PI's thrice-offered liberal learning seminar in animal behavior. Several of these students went on to become biology majors, in part because they enjoyed the seminar course. Along the way, one post-doc and the PI developed an educational software toolkit for the liberal learning seminar; this toolkit (which is distinct from the dynamic-linkage research application) has been posted to the "source forge" website as open-source Matlab code, and a paper summarizing our findings is in review by an education journal. The seminar course and the code we developed accomplished the goal of generating course materials that behavioral ecologists can use to excite students.

Finally, in the proposal, the PI detailed a post-doctoral mentoring plan designed to help train future faculty members. Toward that end, two post-docs received valuable training and experience as educators, and both post-docs secured employment as adjunct faculty members after completing their positions with the PI. Furthermore, one former post-doc has secured a tenure-track faculty position at a sister institution (UNC-Pembroke) and is currently in her second year as a junior faculty member. Clearly, the post-doctoral mentoring plan was successful at training up-and-coming faculty members.

This career project achieved the major aims set out by the PI in the proposal. The project (1) furthered the PI's research career by enabling the development of a Matlab computer program that can be used far into the future to conduct additional research into behavior ecology; (2) excited undergraduate students about behavioral ecology in the research lab and the classroom; (3) attracted members of under-represented minorities into the field; and (4) trained post-docs in science education. Clearly, this project fulfilled the goals of the CAREER program, by helping the PI to "build a firm foundation for a lifetime of leadership in integrating education and research."
